Três milhões. Eles tão oferecendo três milhões por, quer dizer, é só terra e uma casa de fazenda velha, né? [nervous laugh] Mas tipo, that's not what it is at all. Meu bisavô, ele literalmente construiu aquele celeiro com as próprias mãos, sabe? [very quietly] Cada tábua. E agora eles querem construir, o quê, luxury condos?

[frustrated] Meu Deus, o problema é que a gente precisa desse dinheiro. As contas médicas da minha mãe tão—elas tão nos afogando. E meus filhos poderiam ir pra faculdade sem empréstimos, which is honestly everything. [pause] Mas aí eu ando por aqueles campos e ainda consigo ouvir a vovó chamando a gente pro jantar, e é como se... [trailing off]

[bitter] Os incorporadores ficam dizendo que somos sortudas. Sortudas! Como se a gente tivesse ganhado na loteria em vez de perder nossa—[shaky voice] desculpa, eu só—my daughter took her first steps in that kitchen. Quatro gerações de primeiros passos naquela mesma cozinha.

Então o que eu faço, hm? [anxious] Pego o dinheiro e basicamente traio todo mundo que veio antes de mim? Ou fico e assisto a gente perder tudo devagar pra impostos e contas? [long pause] Eu fico pensando que o papai entenderia, but honestly? [very sad] I think it would break his heart either way.

original_conversation.content:
Three million. They're offering us three million for, I mean, it's just dirt and an old farmhouse, right? [nervous laugh] But like, that's not—that's not what it is at all. My great-grandfather, he literally built that barn with his bare hands, you know? [very quietly] Every single board. And now they want to put up, what, luxury condos? 

[frustrated] God, the thing is, we need this money. Mom's medical bills are just—they're drowning us. And my kids could actually go to college without loans, which is, honestly, that's everything. [pause] But then I walk through those fields and I can still hear Grandma calling us in for supper, and it's like... [trailing off]

[bitter] The developers keep saying we're lucky. Lucky! As if we won some lottery instead of losing our whole—[shaky voice] sorry, I just—my daughter took her first steps in that kitchen. Four generations of first steps in that same kitchen. 

So what do I do, hm? [anxious] Take the money and basically betray everyone who came before me? Or stay and watch us slowly lose it anyway to taxes and bills? [long pause] I keep thinking Dad would understand, but honestly? [very sad] I think it would break his heart either way.
